[SYNTAX]: Complex, lengthy sentences with multiple nested clauses.

[STRUCTURE]: Anecdotes (e.g., chairman’s library, Colonial squatter) feel loosely connected to the broader definition of "bookman."
[CLARITY]: Assumes reader familiarity with literary references (e.g., Elia, Spenser) without contextualization.

[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary (e.g., "gay world," "sinewy English") and complex sentence structures may impede readability for modern readers.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, convoluted phrasing (e.g., "He is proudly conscious...").

[STRUCTURE]: Loose thematic transitions between paragraphs (e.g., shifting from literary criticism to personal book preferences).
[CLARITY]: Assumed cultural/literary knowledge (e.g., references to Sainte-Beuve, Benvenuto Cellini) may create gaps for unfamiliar readers.

[LEXICON]: Inconsistent placeholder terms ("a thing", "the stuff") instead of proper titles.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally awkward sentence structures (e.g., "whether imagination has been at work or not I do not know").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between book references (e.g., from Dumas to Balzac without clear connectors).
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential comparisons (e.g., _Henry Esmond_ vs. _Heart of Midlothian_) that slightly disrupt thematic flow.
